report_title: IBISWorld | Automobile & Light Duty Motor Vehicle Manufacturing in the US Jun 2024
executive_summary: The Automobile and Light Duty Motor Vehicle Manufacturing industry has faced significant challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, supply chain disruptions, and economic volatility, leading to a projected 0.5% decline in revenue at a CAGR of 0.5% to $363.9 billion through 2024. However, innovation in electric and autonomous vehicles, along with an economic recovery, is expected to drive a rebound with revenue growing at a 1.6% CAGR to $393.3 billion through 2029. Profit margins are projected to increase from 3.7% in 2019 to 6.1% in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Automakers have faced severe economic volatility because of the pandemic and rampant inflation. The pandemic slashed consumer confidence, encouraging consumers to save excess income rather than spend on new vehicles and other big-ticket purchases. Similarly, lockdown restrictions reduced driving activity, decreasing the need for new cars.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply chain disruptions pose major challenges for automakers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Automobile manufacturers have endured severe supply chain disruptions following the pandemic, the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and other regional conflicts. For example, climbing crude oil prices have had a massive impact on most facets of the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pent-up demand for travel supports most key markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 lockdown measures slashed travel capacity for most consumers, leading to fewer car purchases and discouraging rental car companies from updating fleets. However, consumers have expressed notable pent-up demand for travel as infection rates declined and federal, state, and local governments lifted lockdown restrictions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Federal, state, and local governments have heavily supported the production and adoption of electric, hybrid and other zero-emission vehicles through programs like the EV Acceleration Challenge, Inflation Reduction Act tax credits, and funding for charging infrastructure under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. The CHIPS and Science Act will also indirectly support automotive supply chains.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: EV manufacturers will face an uncertain future
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: EV demand cooled at the end of the current period, with sales falling below estimates. Automakers have struggled to generate positive returns on current EV models, and must work to create more affordable EVs. Foreign producers like BYD have made strides in affordable, long-distance EVs, but face high tariffs. Companies will also lean into hybrid technology as an intermediary.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Autonomous driving remains a long-term ambition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Automakers have started to include lane monitoring, braking software, and parking assistance in higher-end vehicles, but truly autonomous vehicles remain a long-term endeavor. Partnerships between tech companies and automakers will become increasingly common as they develop new AI-enabled technologies, though setbacks have delayed progress.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies must prioritize ethical supply chains
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Companies have faced challenges regarding supply chain ethics, with the US government banning suppliers from the Xinjiang region in China over questions of forced labor. Public and government pressure may also encourage automakers to more heavily scrutinize sustainability and transparency in their supply chains.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling inflation will support consumer demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As interest rates and inflation normalize through the outlook period, consumers will take advantage of falling loan rates and increased disposable income to purchase more expensive vehicles, including electric models. Falling oil prices will also encourage more driving and vehicle replacement.

industry_definition: The Automobile and Light Duty Motor Vehicle Manufacturing industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing automobiles, light trucks (including pickup trucks, vans, and sport utility vehicles) and chassis for these vehicles.

positive_impact_factors: Government support for electric and hybrid vehicles
Pent-up demand for travel and new vehicles post-pandemic
Falling inflation and interest rates boosting consumer demand
negative_impact_factors: Economic volatility from the pandemic and inflation
High costs of developing new electric and autonomous technologies

key_trends: Increasing focus on developing affordable and long-range electric vehicles
Partnerships between automakers and tech companies for autonomous driving systems
Government incentives and infrastructure investments supporting EV adoption
Supply chain challenges related to semiconductors and ethical sourcing
Cooling EV demand and struggles for profitability in the EV market

market_segmentation.segment_description: Crossovers and SUVs have become especially popular, offering more space, raised ground clearance and stylish alternatives to minivans for families.
Pickup trucks are extremely popular in the US for their ability to handle poor road conditions, extensive storage space, and suitability for manual labor.
This wide segment includes compact, midsize, luxury and sports cars catering to various markets focused on cost, fuel efficiency, performance or status.

products_and_services.product_description: CUVs share a chassis with smaller passenger vehicles for better fuel efficiency but offer more space and raised ground clearance.
SUVs use a purpose-built chassis for rugged terrain but have lower fuel economy than CUVs.
Minivans offer ample storage space compared to cars but have been largely cannibalized by the SUV market.
Pickup trucks have long life spans, ability to handle poor roads, and extensive storage space, making them ideal for manual labor.
This includes compact, subcompact, midsize, luxury and sports cars with various powertrains catering to different consumer preferences.

tier_1_suppliers: Motor Vehicle Engine and Engine Parts Manufacturing
Motor Vehicle Steering and Suspension Component Manufacturing

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Growth in disposable income and consumer confidence has driven affluent buyers toward more luxurious and expensive vehicles like SUVs.
SUVs often have lower fuel economy, so consumers are more likely to purchase CUVs or compact hybrids when gas prices rise.
Many automakers are incorporating fuel-efficient technologies into crossovers, drawing buyers seeking to reduce their carbon footprint.

international_trade_points.trade_description: More than 25.0% of automobile imports originate in Mexico due to lower wage costs and reduced trade barriers under USMCA.
Japanese and South Korean manufacturers like Honda, Hyundai and Toyota account for a significant portion of imports.
Canada accounts for over 40.0% of exports due to proximity and favorable trade policies like USMCA.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes is the historic home of the auto industry in the United States. Automakers in the Great Lakes use existing manufacturing infrastructure, supply chains and trade routes to boost revenue. Many companies operate in this region to forge stronger relationships with key buyers and suppliers.

The Southeast region has the largest population in the United States and limited public transportation infrastructure, contributing to steady demand for new vehicles and providing an expansive labor force. The region's access to major ports and trade routes also facilitates trade with Mexico and Europe.

California has a large, highly affluent population, contributing to the region's robust auto market. The state also boasts access to trade routes with Mexico, Canada and Asia, making it an ideal location for many automakers. The Western US is also a major technology hub. Many automakers operate here to collaborate with tech companies for major innovations, like hybrid and electric vehicles or autonomous driving.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Automakers must navigate complex regulations on emissions, safety standards and union demands, creating legal barriers.
Massive start-up costs for facilities, machinery and optimized high-volume production deter new entrants.
Established brands with consumer loyalty from decades of marketing pose significant differentiation challenges for new entrants.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies must constantly innovate new vehicle technologies like electric and self-driving systems to attract consumers.
Automakers differentiate vehicles through branding, pricing, features and quality to appeal to different consumer segments.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Large automakers operate multiple product lines appealing to different markets, income levels and preferences.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Inputs are the main cost for automakers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the largest cost for automakers; metals, like aluminum and steel, represent the largest input for manufacturers. Companies have increasingly shifted to aluminum to produce lighter, more fuel-efficient bodies. Steel prices also rose more than 110.0% during the pandemic, encouraging automakers to substitute with aluminum. Semiconductor shortages have also led to elevated purchase costs. Automakers use semiconductors for most electronic systems, like radios, GPS, entertainment systems, and driver assistance. These shortages have led to skyrocketing car prices in recent years.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Companies have poured capital into research, development and skilled labor
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Companies have poured capital into research, development and skilled labor. Automakers have scrambled to produce hybrid, electric and self-driving vehicles to gain a competitive edge as consumer preferences and government regulations shift.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Automakers largely rely on strong economic conditions to generate new car sales. The pandemic and supply chain disruptions represented severe exogenous shocks for global automobile manufacturers. Surging supply costs have also contributed to volatile profit through the current period. Periods of severe undersupply and inventory overflows eroded consistent profitability for most automakers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Companies have struggled to generate positive returns on electric vehicles
volatility_points.volatility_description: Companies have also struggled to generate positive returns on electric vehicles, with Ford and GM reporting significant losses in EV production. Conversely, foreign manufacturers in the US, like Honda and Toyota, have reported robust returns on hybrid vehicles. Companies may increasingly prioritize hybrid vehicles as an intermediate goal to carbon-neutral production to salvage profit.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Companies have poured capital into research, development and skilled labor
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies have poured capital into research, development and skilled labor. Automakers have scrambled to produce hybrid, electric and self-driving vehicles to gain a competitive edge as consumer preferences and government regulations shift.

FAQs.question: What is the largest cost for automobile manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: Purchases, which account for 77.2% of revenue. This includes inputs like metals, semiconductors, and battery materials.

FAQs.question: What factors influence wage costs for automakers?
FAQs.answer: Union demands, particularly from the United Auto Workers Union, as well as the need for skilled labor to develop new technologies like electric and self-driving vehicles.

FAQs.question: What challenges do automakers face in terms of profitability?
FAQs.answer: Automakers face cyclical profits tied to economic conditions and new vehicle sales. They have also struggled to generate positive returns on electric vehicles specifically.

FAQs.question: What are some key financial ratios and benchmarks for the industry?
FAQs.answer: The industry has an average EBIT/Revenue ratio around 5%, a leverage ratio around 15, and revenue per employee around $1.7 million in recent years. Wages account for around 5% of revenue.
